raw_text:
Mourinho to escape FA charge
 
 Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho will not face any Football Association action over the comments he made after their Carling Cup tie with Manchester United.
 
 Mourinho intimated that United boss Sir Alex Ferguson influenced referee Neale Barry after the duo walked down the tunnel together at half-time. But an FA spokesman told BBC Sport: "We are not taking action over Mourinho. "We have looked at the comments and we have decided that no further action is required. That is the end of it." Mourinho was concerned that Ferguson's conversation with Barry was followed by an inconsistent display by the official. "I see one referee in the first half and another in the second," said Mourinho. "If the FA ask me what happened, I will tell them. What I saw and felt made it easier to understand a few things.
 
 "Maybe when I turn 60 and have been managing in the same league for 20 years and have the respect of everybody I will have the power to speak to people and make them tremble a little bit. "The referee controlled the game in one way during the first half but in the second they had dozens of free-kicks. It was fault after fault, dive after dive. "But I know the referee did not walk to the dressing rooms alone at half-time. He should only have had his two assistants and the fourth official with him, but there was also someone else." Referees chief Keith Hackett believes Mourinho should retract his comments about Ferguson and Barry as he believes the Blues boss has questioned their integrity. "I'm hoping he might reconsider his comments, unfortunately this is the nature of the game," said Hackett. "I don't want referees or myself getting in the psychological warfare between two managers. For the second leg we have an experienced referee, and we should be talking about the quality of that game rather than the refereeing. "Sometimes managers have grounds for comments, and I note that, but a referees integrity has been questioned, that is offensive and should be avoided. Mr Mourinho should look at the facts." Mourinho added that the match was entertaining for a goalless draw and insisted his team could still reach the final. "It's 0-0, so if we win we go through and if we get a draw we go to extra time," he said. "We have exactly the same chance we had before this game. "We are confident of getting a result but we know what Manchester United is, a footballing power. It'll be difficult for us, but also for them."
llama3.2:1b: Jose Mourinho will not face FA action over comments made after Chelsea's Carling Cup tie with Manchester United. An FA spokesman stated that they have looked at the comments and decided no further action is required. Mourinho expressed concern about referee Neale Barry following their half-time conversation, criticizing his inconsistent display throughout the game.
llama3.2:3b: Jose Mourinho will not face FA action over comments he made about Manchester United's referee Neale Barry at half-time during their Carling Cup tie with United. Mourinho claimed that Ferguson influenced the referee after they walked down the tunnel together, sparking a warning from Referees chief Keith Hackett. However, an FA spokesman stated there would be no further action, citing no grounds for intervention.
gemma2:2b: Jose Mourinho will not face FA charges for comments about referee Neale Barry following Chelsea's Carling Cup tie with Manchester United.  Mourinho claimed that Sir Alex Ferguson influenced the referee during halftime, leading to an inconsistent performance by Barry in the second half. While Referee Keith Hackett urged him to retract his comments and focus on the game quality, Mourinho defended his stance, claiming inconsistencies from the official. He also acknowledged Chelsea's chances of advancing in the competition.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Chelsea coach Jose Mourinho will not face any FA action over comments he made after their Carling Cup tie with Manchester United.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho will not face Football Association action over alleged comments about Manchester United boss Sir Alex Ferguson influencing referee after their Carling Cup tie. Mourinho criticized the inconsistency in refereeing during the match and claimed Ferguson had a conversation with the official before halftime that affected the officials' performance. Mourinho has since retracted his comments, acknowledging the issue is related to integrity rather than his managerial ability. The FA spokesman stated they are not taking any further action regarding the remarks.
qwen2.5:3b: Jose Mourinho will not face Football Association charges over comments about referee Neale Barry and Manchester United boss Sir Alex Ferguson following their Carling Cup match. The FA decided no further action was required after reviewing Mourinho's remarks. Mourinho claimed there were inconsistencies in the referee's behavior during the game, suggesting he had influence from Ferguson. Referees chief Keith Hackett urged Mourinho to retract his comments, as it questioned referees' integrity and suggested a psychological warfare between managers. Mourinho defended Chelsea's chances of reaching the final despite the 0-0 draw.

Mourinho intimated that United boss Sir Alex Ferguson influenced referee Neale Barry after the duo walked down the tunnel together at half-time. smollm:1.7b:
Mourinho will not face any Football Association action over the comments he made after their Carling Cup tie with Manchester United. Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho intimated that United boss Sir Alex Ferguson influenced referee Neale Barry after the duo walked down the tunnel together at half-time. But an FA spokesman told BBC Sport: "We are not taking action over Mourinho. We have looked at the comments and we have decided that no further action is required." Mourinho was concerned that Ferguson's conversation with Barry was followed by an inconsistent display by the official. "I see one referee in the first half and another in the second," said Mourinho. "If the FA ask me what happened, I will tell them. What I saw and felt made it easier to understand a few things.
 
 "Maybe when I turn 60 and have been managing in the same league for 20 years and have the respect of everybody I will have the power to speak to people and make them tremble a little bit. The referee controlled the game in one way during the first half but in the second they had dozens of free-kicks. It was fault after fault, dive after dive. "But I know the referee did not walk to the dressing rooms alone at half-time. He should only have had his two assistants and the fourth official with him, but there was also someone else." Referees chief Keith Hackett believes Mourinho should retract his comments about Ferguson and Barry as he believes the referee's integrity has been questioned. "I'm hoping he might reconsider his comments, unfortunately this is the nature of the game," said Hackett. "I don't want referees or myself getting in the psychological warfare between two managers. For the second leg we have an experienced referee, and we should be talking about the quality of that game rather than the refereeing. Mr Mourinho should look at the facts." Mourinho added that the match was entertaining for a goalless draw and insisted his team could still reach the final. "It's 0-0, so if we win we get through to extra time. We have exactly the same chance we had before this game. We are confident of getting a result but we know what Manchester United is, a footballing power. It'll be difficult for us, but also for them."

First, Mourinho isn't in trouble because he didn't mention anything wrong with Ferguson's conversation with Barry during the tie. The BBC Sport article says they took no action against him. Then Mourinho explained that he saw one referee in the first half and another later. He thinks the second half had too many mistakes, like free kicks and dives.

Hackett, the referee chief, thinks Mourinho should retract his comments because referees need to have integrity. He wants the Blue team to keep talking about their game, not just their refereeing. He also mentions that Manchester United is a strong team and challenging for Chelsea. The match was fun, so they're aiming for an equal result.

So, I need to condense this into a summary without adding any extra info or explanations. Mourinho won't face an FA charge over his comments about Ferguson's conversation with Barry during their Chelsea vs. Manchester United game. The BBC Sport article stated they took no action against Mourinho, who explained he saw a referee in the first half and another later. He noted inconsistent refereeing, particularly free kicks and dives in the second half. Referee chief Keith Hackett wants Mourinho to address his comments on integrity. Manchester United is a tough team, and Chelsea aims for an equal result but knows Manchester United's strength. The match was fun with a 0-0 draw.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Football Association has decided not to take action against Mourinho after his comments about Manchester United following the Carlisle Cup tie. The FA stated that they have looked into the specific allegations made by Moulinho and found no evidence to support them. Moulinho's concern for inconsistencies in the match was seen as an attempt to speak to officials, but it was noted that he did not have his assistant or fourth official with him during the first half. The Manchester United manager, Sir Alex Ferguson, reportedly influenced comments made by a fellow referee after the game. Despite this, the FA has decided not to take action against Moulinho and has noted that the match was entertaining for a goalless draw and that his team could still reach the final if they win.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Mourinho appeared on BBC Sport after a 0-0 Carling Cup tie with Manchester United, insisting that his team could still reach the final despite being held to a goalless draw. He was also criticized by former Chelsea manager and referee Neale Barry, who was on the field with him during the match. However, an FA spokesman said there would be no further action taken against Mourinho.
phi:2.7b: Chelsea manager Mourinho did not face any charges from the FA over his comments after their Carling Cup match against Manchester United. He expressed concern that referee Neale Barry may have been influenced by Manchester United's former boss Sir Alex Ferguson and observed what he felt were multiple fouls during the game, despite an inconsistent display by Barry. The FA spokesman denied taking action against Mourinho and the Blues boss should retract his comments about Ferguson and Barry. Referees chief Keith Hackett believes that it is inappropriate for managers to engage in psychological warfare and that they should focus on the quality of the match instead. Despite the draw, Mourinho remains confident that his team can still reach the final.
orca-mini:3b: Jose Mourinho will not face any Football Association action over his comments about Manchester United boss Sir Alex Ferguson and referee Neale Barry after the duo walked down the tunnel together at half-time. The Chelsea manager intimated that Ferguson influenced the official following their Carling Cup tie. However, an FA spokesman told BBC Sport that no further action was required.
hermes3:3b: Jose Mourinho won't face FA action over comments about Sir Alex Ferguson influencing referee after halftime in Chelsea-Man Utd Carling Cup match.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho will not face FA action over comments accusing Sir Alex Ferguson and referee Neale Barry of conspiring against his team during their Carling Cup tie with Manchester United. An FA spokesman confirmed that no further action is required, as they have looked into the matter and decided it is settled. Referees chief Keith Hackett urged Mourinho to retract his comments about Ferguson and Barry, believing the manager's words questioned the integrity of referees.

Mourinho expressed concerns over inconsistent officiating, implying Ferguson's halftime conversation with Barry affected the second half. Referees chief Keith Hackett urged Mourinho to retract his remarks, stating they questioned the integrity of officials. Mourinho defended his stance but remained confident in Chelsea's chances of reaching the final despite the goalless draw.
stablelm2:1.6b: Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho will not face any Football Association action over comments he made about Sir Alex Ferguson and referee Neale Barry following their Carling Cup tie. Mourinho suggested that Ferguson influenced the ref, but an FA spokesman said they have reviewed the comments and no further action is required. Mourinho believes referees should avoid questioning a team's integrity during games.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho will not face FA charges over allegations he suggested Sir Alex Ferguson influenced the Carling Cup match referee, Neale Barry. Mourinho expressed concerns about a perceived change in Barry's performance post-halftime, citing an abundance of free-kicks and potential diving. Despite his comments, the FA decided not to take further action due to insufficient evidence of referee manipulation. Referees chief Keith Hackett urged Mourinho to retract his remarks, deeming them offensive to referee integrity. Mourinho maintained that a goalless draw leaves Chelsea with the same chance as Manchester United to advance in the competition.
reference: "I see one referee in the first half and another in the second," said Mourinho.Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho will not face any Football Association action over the comments he made after their Carling Cup tie with Manchester United.Mourinho intimated that United boss Sir Alex Ferguson influenced referee Neale Barry after the duo walked down the tunnel together at half-time.Mourinho was concerned that Ferguson's conversation with Barry was followed by an inconsistent display by the official."The referee controlled the game in one way during the first half but in the second they had dozens of free-kicks.But an FA spokesman told BBC Sport: "We are not taking action over Mourinho.Referees chief Keith Hackett believes Mourinho should retract his comments about Ferguson and Barry as he believes the Blues boss has questioned their integrity.For the second leg we have an experienced referee, and we should be talking about the quality of that game rather than the refereeing.Mourinho added that the match was entertaining for a goalless draw and insisted his team could still reach the final.He should only have had his two assistants and the fourth official with him, but there was also someone else."
